inlineContent.text: Learn how to exclude specific properties from observation.
Efficiently manage caches, temporary data, and heavy computation results.
This is useful for performance optimization and intentional update prevention.
It’s appropriate for internal state that doesn’t need view updates.
Carefully judge whether view updates are really unnecessary.
Cache computed results without triggering view updates.
Store service objects that don’t need observation.
Separate development/analytics purpose data from views.
Let’s look at practical use cases for @ObservationIgnored.
Useful for caches, dependency injection, debug info, etc.
Frequently accessed but doesn’t need view updates.
Record user behavior but don’t affect the UI.
Service objects don’t need to redraw views when changed.
Good for caches, analytics data, service dependencies -
Cache data or internal state not displayed in views
Even if it changes frequently, if it’s displayed in views,
Use as much as possible for performance optimization
Indiscriminate use creates bugs where views don’t update.
from the observation system, so no change notifications are sent.
Views are updated like normal properties
are not notified to the observation system.
What happens when a property with @ObservationIgnored changes?
